abstract.li: the specification of elements of a product shape as being derived from other elements of shape;
the naming of the kind of the relationship of the derived shape element to the shape element(s) from which it is derived.

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of shape elements that are derived from other shape elements. It provides a general means for specifying a set of points as having been derived from elements of a the shape of a part.

The derived shape element has a deriving relationship to another shape element. The deriving relationship can exist between shape elements that participate in the specification and verification of geometric dimensions and tolerances that are imposed as requirements on the product shape.
purpose.example: The axis of a hole can be derived from the cylindrical surface of the hole.
purpose.p: The outputs of operations of specification and verification can be related to the inputs.

example.p: The following are examples of operations used in the verification or specification of product shape.

ul.li: creating a cross section curve by intersecting a plane and a feature;
mathematically fitting a circle to a cross section;
calculating the center point of a circle;
collecting points to form a locus.

purpose.p: The classification and definition of such operations is outside the scope of this part of ISO 10303.
This part of ISO 10303 does not limit the use of deriving relationships between shape elements any particular application context.
purpose.example: The geometry of derived shape elements is construction geometry, and the geometric construction operations can be used in creating the geometry that represents a derived shape element.
purpose.p: A derived shape element need not have a representation.
purpose.example: A hole is a shape element that is represented by a non uniform rational b-spline surface that is cylindrical. The axis is specified as a derived shape element, but with no explicit representation. A straightness tolerance is applied to the axis of a hole.

inscope.li: the specification of elements of a product shape as being derived from other elements of shape;

the naming of the kind of the relationship of the derived shape element to the shape element(s) from which it is derived;'centre of symmetry', 'apex of cone', 'geometric alignment', 'perpendicular to', 'geometric intersection, 'extension', 'tangent', and 'parallel offset' are examples of types of derived shape element.
items within the scope of application module Construction geometry, ISO/CD-TS 10303-1131;
items within the scope of application module Shape property assignment, ISO/CD-TS 10303-1032;
items within the scope of application module Value with unit, ISO/TS 10303-1054.

outscope.li: the standardization of the kinds of deriving relationships and their meanings.

definition.def: general term for portion or aspect of something

general term for any aspect or element of a shape which need not lie on the boundary nor even within the material of the shape A hole feature is a shape element. The axis of a hole is a shape element. The terms feature and element are in some standards reserved for the more restrictive sense of integral shape element.
portion of the shape that lies entirely on the surface of the shape The cylindrical surface of a hole feature is an integral shape element.

shape element that is related to an integral shape element The axis of a hole is a derived shape element. In some standards the term derived is reserved for the case where the relating shape element is not itself an integral shape element.
